selected_quotes: #MetaCover: p38ɣ/Δ control heart growth response to hypertension

citation.abstract: Disrupted organ growth leads to disease development. Hypertrophy underlies postnatal heart growth and is triggered after stress, but the molecular mechanisms involved in these processes are largely unknown. Here we show that cardiac activation of p38γ and p38δ increases during postnatal development and by hypertrophy-inducing stimuli. p38γ/δ promote cardiac hypertrophy by phosphorylating the mTORC1 and mTORC2 inhibitor DEPTOR, which leads to its degradation and mTOR activation. Hearts from mice lacking one or both kinases are below normal size, have high levels of DEPTOR, low activity of the mTOR pathway and reduced protein synthesis. The phenotype of p38γ/δ(-/-) mice is reverted by overactivation of mTOR with amino acids, shRNA-mediated knockdown of Deptor, or cardiomyocyte overexpression of active p38γ and p38δ. Moreover, in WT mice, heart weight is reduced by cardiac overexpression of DEPTOR. Our results demonstrate that p38γ/δ control heart growth by modulating mTOR pathway through DEPTOR phosphorylation and subsequent degradation.
citation.title: p38[gamma] and [delta] promote heart hypertrophy by targeting the mTOR-inhibitory protein DEPTOR for degradation

news.title: How heart grows and adapts to high blood pressure
news.summary: A new study has identified how two proteins control the growth of the heart and its adaptation to high blood pressure (hypertension).

news.title: Two key proteins that control heart growth identified
news.summary: London, Jan 23 (IANS) Researchers have identified how two proteins control the growth of the heart and its adaptation to high blood pressure that can help design new strategies to treat heart failure caused by excessive growth of the heart.

news.title: How Heart Growth and Its Adaptation To High Blood Pressure is Controlled By Two Proteins
